title.value: Multi-variable Hard Physical Constraints for Climate Model Downscaling
title.justification: The title is provided at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Multi-variable Hard Physical Constraints for Climate Model Downscaling

extractions.description: This paper investigates the limitations of independent downscaling of climate variables using deep learning methods, which often violate physical properties between related variables. The authors introduce a framework that incorporates multi-variable hard constraints, ensuring physically-consistent downscaling of climate models.

type.justification: The paper involves experimentation with deep learning models and evaluates their performance in downscaling climate models while ensuring physical consistency.
type.quote: To address this, we have proposed a shared model for the desired variables as a partial solution. However, to ensure multi-variable physical constraints, we have introduced a simple and flexible framework that satisfies hard constraints and achieves the same performance or better than standard approaches.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on the downscaling of Global Climate Models (GCMs) using deep learning techniques.
name.quote: Global Climate Models (GCMs) are the primary tool to simulate climate evolution and assess the impacts of climate change.

name.justification: The paper discusses the limitations and proposed solutions for downscaling climate models to a finer spatial resolution.
name.quote: Statistical Downscaling (SD) techniques attempt to overcome this limitation by learning a relationship between large-scale (low-resolution) data and local-scale (high-resolution) variables of interest.

name.justification: Deep learning methods are examined for their efficacy in downscaling climate models and maintaining physical constraints.
name.quote: Deep Learning (DL) has recently emerged as a promising SD method, with great potential given its ability to handle spatio-temporal data and model non-linear relationships.

name.justification: UNet is used as one of the models for downscaling climate variables in the study.
name.quote: We train two different DL models: UNet (Ronneberger et al., 2015) and DeepESD (Baño-Medina et al., 2022).

is_contributed.justification: UNet is an existing model utilized in the study.
is_contributed.quote: UNet is a fully-convolutional model inspired by an architecture widely used in image segmentation.

is_executed.justification: UNet was trained and evaluated on test data.
is_executed.quote: The models are trained using the ERA-Interim and W5E5 data sets as predictor and predictand fields, respectively.

is_compared.justification: UNet's performance is compared to DeepESD in the experimental results.
is_compared.quote: Figure 2 shows the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) values on the test set obtained for the two DL models trained, namely UNet and DeepESD, for the different experiments.
